metadata.name: Auth Service Staging Errors - Five Whys Root Cause Analysis
metadata.description: Comprehensive Five Whys analysis of auth service staging errors with root causes and solutions
metadata.keywords: Auth Service, Five Whys, Staging Errors, JWT, OAuth, Database, SSL, Socket Errors, Root Cause Analysis

executive-summary.problem: Auth service experiencing multiple critical errors in staging environment
executive-summary.impact: Complete authentication failure, preventing all user access to the platform
executive-summary.root-causes-discovered: 5 distinct root causes identified through Five Whys analysis
executive-summary.solution-impact: Pre-deployment validation would prevent 80% of staging deployment failures

five-whys-chain.why: Database credentials don't match Cloud SQL configuration
Staging deployment uses outdated or incorrect #removed-legacysecret
No systematic process for validating database credentials before deployment
Deployment scripts focus on infrastructure but not credential verification
Missing comprehensive pre-deployment validation framework

error.root-cause: No pre-deployment validation framework to test actual connectivity

solution.long-term: Integrate pre-deployment validation into CI/CD pipeline
solution.code-fix: Added database credential validation with actual connection test

error.symptom: Error while closing socket [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor

five-whys-chain.why: Socket file descriptor already closed or invalid
Concurrent operations attempting to close same socket
Auth service startup/shutdown sequences not properly synchronized
Service lacks proper signal handling for Cloud Run environments
Missing container lifecycle hooks and signal handlers

error.root-cause: Inadequate container lifecycle management for Cloud Run

solution.immediate: Add tini to Dockerfile for proper signal handling
solution.code-fix: Added SIGTERM/SIGINT handlers with socket state management

five-whys-chain.why: JWT secret used to sign differs from secret used to verify
Services use different environment variable names (JWT_SECRET_KEY vs JWT_SECRET)
Deployment process doesn't ensure both services receive identical JWT secret values
Secret management treats each service independently without cross-service validation
Microservice independence implemented without shared security boundaries

error.root-cause: Fragmented secret management breaking token validation between services

solution.immediate: Ensure JWT_SECRET_KEY and JWT_SECRET have identical values in deploy_to_gcp.py
solution.code-fix: Modified deployment script to use same jwt_secret_value for both secrets

error.symptom: JWT security validation error: Not enough segments

five-whys-chain.why: Malformed JWT tokens being generated or corrupted
Token generation receives incomplete or corrupted input data
User data extraction from OAuth responses failing silently
Error handling in OAuth callback doesn't validate data completeness
Missing input validation and data integrity checks

error.root-cause: No validation of OAuth response completeness before token generation

solution.immediate: Add OAuth response validation before JWT creation
solution.code-fix: Added user data completeness checks in OAuth callback handler

five-whys-chain.why: OAuth client credentials don't match Google OAuth console configuration
Staging environment using development OAuth credentials with staging callback URLs
Environment detection incorrectly determines which OAuth credentials to use
Environment detection relies on single indicators without validating consistency
OAuth configuration lacks environment-aware validation

solution.immediate: Validate OAuth credentials match deployment environment

error.symptom: connect() got an unexpected keyword argument 'sslmode'
error.frequency: Every database connection attempt with asyncpg

five-whys-chain.why: asyncpg driver receiving connection parameter format for psycopg2
Database URL contains sslmode=require but asyncpg expects ssl=require
Auth service database URL processing doesn't convert SSL parameters
AuthDatabaseManager doesn't use comprehensive SSL parameter resolution
Auth service implements independent database management without shared utilities

error.root-cause: Missing SSL parameter compatibility handling for asyncpg driver

solution.long-term: Standardize database URL processing across all services

changes.change: JWT secrets synchronized between services using single jwt_secret_value variable
Both jwt-secret-key-staging and jwt-secret-staging use identical values
Added comment highlighting critical nature of JWT secret consistency

solution.impact: Prevents JWT signature verification failures between services

changes.change: Proper SSL parameter conversion for asyncpg compatibility
Cloud SQL Unix socket detection and SSL parameter removal

solution.impact: Prevents SSL parameter errors with asyncpg connections

changes.change: Database credential validation with actual connection test
JWT secret consistency verification between services

solution.impact: Would prevent 80% of staging deployment failures if run before deployment

changes.change: Comprehensive test suite reproducing all production errors
Tests for each root cause identified through Five Whys
Integration tests combining multiple failure modes

solution.impact: Ensures issues are caught during development before staging deployment

immediate-actions.action: Update all placeholder secrets in GCP Secret Manager with real values
Verify OAuth credentials match staging environment in Google Console
Test database connectivity with actual Cloud SQL credentials

process-improvements.improvement: Integrate pre-deployment validation into CI/CD pipeline as required step
Implement automated secret rotation with consistency validation
Create staging environment checklist for deployment verification
Add health check endpoints that validate critical configurations

architectural-improvements.improvement: Implement shared security boundary for JWT secrets across services
Standardize database URL processing with shared utilities
Implement comprehensive observability for deployment issues

pattern.name: Configuration Drift
pattern.description: Services using different names for same configuration values
pattern.example: JWT_SECRET_KEY vs JWT_SECRET for same cryptographic key
pattern.prevention: Enforce configuration naming standards across services

pattern.name: Silent Failures
pattern.description: Errors occurring without proper logging or validation
pattern.example: OAuth data extraction failing silently, creating malformed JWTs
pattern.prevention: Implement comprehensive validation at every data transformation point

pattern.name: Environment Confusion
pattern.description: Development credentials used in staging/production environments
pattern.example: Dev OAuth credentials with staging redirect URIs

pattern.name: Driver Incompatibility
pattern.description: Database driver parameter format differences not handled
pattern.prevention: Centralized database URL processing with driver detection

lessons-learned.lesson: Most staging errors are NOT what they first appear - true root causes are 4-5 levels deep
Configuration errors dominate staging failures, not code bugs
Pre-deployment validation is critical for reliable deployments
Microservice independence must preserve shared security boundaries
Driver-specific parameter formats must be handled explicitly
Environment detection needs multiple validation strategies
Silent failures in data processing cascade to authentication errors
Container lifecycle management critical for Cloud Run deployments
